Project Description 

The Project is located in  Xi’an municipality, the capital of Shaanxi 
Province  and a key growth pole  in the poor western region of the 
PRC.  In  Xi’an,  the  urban  population  increased  from  2.3  million 
(37.3%  of  total)  in  1990  to  3.0  million  (42.7%)  in  2002.  Rapid 
urbanization  in  Xi’an  has  put  pressure  on  the  urban  transport 
system, resulting in traffic congestion and increasing motor vehicle 
emission.  The Project will support the Government’s  development 
strategy by improving the urban transport system by (i) constructing 
an  urban  ring  road;  (ii)  improving  connector  roads ;  (iii) providing 
urban transport facilities and services; and (iv) providing consulting 
services and training to enhance construction quality,  road safety, 
vehicle emission control, and project monitoring and evaluation.  

Consistent  with  the  Xi’an  master  plan,  large  investments  are 
programmed  for  road  construction,  a  subway  system,  and  public 
transport operations. Clear and realistic priorities need to be set for 
future  urban  development.  Policy  and  institutional  reforms  are 
needed  in urban transport policy and regulations, public transport, 
traffic management and safety, road maintenance, vehicle emission 
control,  driver  education,  urban  poverty  reduction,  and  private 
the 
sector  development.  The  master  plan  gives  priority 
construction of the third ring road, which will form the main physical 
component  of  the  Project.  Construction  of  a  ring  road  and 
connector  roads  will  provide  efficient  and  safe  access  within  the 
city, and for inbound and outbound traffic. The Project will address 
the  growing  traffic  congestion  caused  by  the  rapid  increase  in 
traffic, inadequate road infrastructure, and poor traffic management. 
The Project has been designed as a public service project because 
people in the urban area  will all benefit from the Project directly or 
indirectly through reduced congestion in the urban road network as 
a  whole.  The  project  road  users,  therefore,  will  not  be  directly 
charged for its use. Xi’an municipality has identified the Project as a 
priority investment, which will also complement ADB’s assistance in 
developing the  Xi’an-Taiyuan section of the national trunk highway 
system.

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

 
A. 
 
2. 
PRC’s  rapid  economic  growth  has  been  accompanied  by  urbanization,  with  the urban 
population increasing from 300 million (26.4% of total) in 1990 to 502 million (39.1%) in 2001. 
This urbanization trend  is forecast to  continue, with the urban population reaching  832 million 
(54.5%)  in  2025.  Increased  incomes  and  prosperity  have  made  cars  affordable  to  a  growing 
segment  of  the  population,  the  emerging  middle  class.  Vehicle  ownership  is  projected  to 
increase  from  18  per  1,000  people  in  2000  by  a  factor  of  more  than  five  in  2020.  In  Xi’an 
municipality  the  urban  population  increased  from  2.3  million  (37.3%  of  total)  in  1990  to  3.0 
million  (42.7%)  in  2002.  This  has  put  increasing  pressure  on  the  urban  transport  system. 
Between 1990 and 2001, when real economic growth averaged 10.4% per annum, road traffic 
grew at 15.7% per annum for passenger traffic, reaching  4.5 billion passenger-kilometers (km); 
and  10.1%  per  annum  for  freight,  reaching  4.0  billion  ton-km.  Movement  of  goods  and 
passengers  will  increasingly  be  by  road,  as  road  transport  is  more  flexible  and  responsive  to 
needs  in  a  market  economy  than  other  modes.  Vehicle  ownership  in  Xi ’an  grew  from  10.1 
vehicles per 1,000 people to 23.1 during the same period. 
 
The road network  in  Xi’an  is  underdeveloped  in  both  quality  and  extent.  The  total  road

4. 
Urban infrastructure  development  during  the  ninth  Five-Year  Plan  (FYP)  (1996–2000)

B. 
 
5. 
Xi’an  is  the  provincial  capital  and  political,  economic,  and  cultural  center  of  Shaanxi 
Province.  Xi ’an  is  one  of  the  most  important  growth  poles  in  the  western  region.  Xi’an 
municipality comprises the city (with eight districts) and five counties, with a total population of 
7.0  million.  Xi’an’s  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  was  CNY82.4  billion  in  2002,  up  by  13.5% 
from 2001. The GDP is expected to grow  by 12.4% per year, reaching  CNY117 billion by 2005.

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

  2

The average annual per capita income for urban residents was CNY7,184, slightly less than the 
national  average  of  CNY7,703.  For  rural  residents  income  per  capita  was  CNY2,641, slightly 
more  than  the  national  average  of  CNY2,476.  The  income  levels  are  forecast  to increase to 
CNY8,864 and CNY3,500, respectively, by 2005.  
 
6. 
The city is located at the junction of two major highways and two major railways. Around 
this  transport  hub,  the  city  has  developed  into  an  important  industrial  and  commercial  center 
with  many  high-tech  industries,  including  electronics,  machinery,  and  pharmaceuticals;  and 
service  sectors,  such  as  information  technology,  finance,  and  insurance.  The  state-level  Xi’an 
Economic  Development  Zone  was  established  in  1988  to  attract  foreign  and  domestic 
investment.  So  far,  20  km2  has  been  developed  at  a  cost  of  CNY4.1  billion  for  infrastructure. 
The  872  enterprises  in  the  zone  have  a  total  investment  of  CNY38  billion.  Inadequate  road 
infrastructure, however, is a major constraint on investment by the private sector.  Many foreign 
companies  will  not  invest  in  the  interior  provinces  because  of  weak  infrastructure.  An  ADB- 
supported survey 2  of domestic firms in Xi’an cited poor roads as the most serious infrastructure 
constraint. 
 
7. 
The  present  urban  transport  infrastructure  and  services  cannot  meet  the  increasing 
traffic  demand  in  Xi’an.  The  incomplete  road  network,  low  standard  of  transport  infrastructure, 
low  flow  capacity  at  surface  intersections,  and  slow  vehicle  speeds  contribute  to  traffic 
congestion, traffic accidents, and increased vehicle emissions. The main causes of urban traffic 
congestion are (i) inadequate road infrastructure facilities and services—road density is low and 
capacity  has  already  been  reached;  (ii)  poor  management  and  maintenance  of  urban  roads—
the existing road space is not efficiently used due to inadequate traffic management and road 
maintenance; (iii) poor public transport services—development is hindered by  lack of capacity, 
slow  operating  speeds,  and  outdated  equipment  and  management  practices;  and  (iv) 
institutional  weakness—inadequate  coordination  between  multiple  agencies  responsible  for 
urban transport policy, planning, regulations, and operations. The consequent impacts on urban 
traffic  congestion  include  (i)  increased  transport  costs  comprising  vehicle  operating  costs 
(VOCs) and time; (ii) increasing air pollution due to vehicle emissions that pose health threats to 
urban residents; and (iii) increasing number and severity of road accidents due to poor driving 
practices, large traffic volumes, and narrow roads. 
 
A  national  symposium,  jointly  sponsored  by  ADB 3  and  the  World  Bank  in  Beijing  in

encouraged. In line with these  principles, the following criteria were  adopted for urban transport 
policies  and  plans:  environmental  sustainability,  economic  viability,  financial  affordability,  and 
social  acceptability.  Consistent  with

9. 
The  development  of  Xi’an  is  guided  by  the  Master  Plan:  1995-2010, which sets out a 
broad policy on land use and development, and transport infrastructure that will conserve Xi’an’s 
unique character, historical legacy, and environment. The  master plan was updated to take into 
account  the  significant  changes  forecast  for  the  next  decade.    It  provides  a  good  basis  for 
planning  urban  transport  development,  including  public  transport.  Urbanization  and  rapid 
economic growth are forecast to continue  throughout the period. A large increase in office and 
commercial activities  is  forecast and  will  be  located  centrally.  To  provide  the required space, 
major redevelopment is planned in and adjacent to the city center. In  the master plan, the Xi’an 
urban area will be supported by 11 peripheral satellite towns that will be home to Xi’an’s growing 
population, industry relocated from the inner city, and new industrial developments. 
 
10. 
For  three  reasons,  good  transport  planning  is  central  to  implementing the  master  plan. 
First, because the demand for road space is growing much more rapidly than the supply, there 
are prospects for increased levels of traffic congestion that afflict many large Asian cities. Traffic 
congestion has direct adverse impacts on the productivity and economic performance of cities, 
and  the  life  styles  of  urban  residents.  Second,  because  transport  systems  fundamentally 
influence land use,  the  master  plan can only be implemented  if  it  is  supported  by  a  transport 
strategy.  Traffic  congestion  is  already  making  Xi’an’s  satellite  towns  inaccessible  and  less 
attractive to people currently living in the city center. Adequate transport links to the city center 
are necessary to make these satellite towns viable. Third,  because Xi’an is Shaanxi Province’s 
cultural center, great importance is attached to preserving and enhancing the city environment. 
While  measures  are  being  taken  to  address  environmental  concerns  from  industrial  and 
commercial  sources, 6  there  is  mounting  evidence  that  increasing  vehicle  emissions  will 
adversely  affect  the  city’s  environment,  including  the  historic  core.  An  appropriate  transport 
strategy is necessary to address the situation. 
 
11. 
The impact of transport infrastructure investments on poverty reduction was analyzed in 
a  study  that  examined  the  effectiveness  of  government  expenditure  in  various  sectors  in 
contributing to growth and poverty reduction in the PRC. The study concluded that investments 
in road infrastructure have  a significant  impact  on  poverty  reduction,  productivity,  and  growth. 
The link between transport  infrastructure  and  poverty  reduction  is  also  supported  by  studies 7 
and  evaluation  of  completed  transport  projects  financed  by  ADB 8  and  the  World  Bank. 9 An 
ongoing  TA  is  examining  the  socioeconomic impact of road investment in  the  PRC10 while a

D. 
 
Lessons  learned  from  the  ADB-financed urban transport  projects18 suggest that it is not 
19. 
cost-effective  to  charge  tolls  on  urban  ring roads and bridges because long lines waiting to pay 
the tolls would spill over into the connector roads causing traffic congestion. The project cost was, 
therefore, recovered from municipal road user charges. Other lessons include (i) the benefits of a 
comprehensive  and  participatory  approach  to  project  preparation,  (ii)  the  benefits  of  a  planned 
and  well-coordinated  resettlement  scheme  preceded  by  adequate  consultation  with  affected 
parties  before  relocation,  and  (iii)  the  need  for  a  professional  approach  to  forecasting  traffic 
demand.  While  these  projects  were  successful,  their  development  impact  would  have  been 
greater if more attention had been paid to issues like traffic management, vehicle emissions, and 
public  transport.  Their  experience  demonstrates  that  the  provision  of  urban  infrastructure  can 
have a profound impact on urban land use. Lessons learned from other externally financed urban 
transport projects19 in the PRC include the following: (i) coordination among agencies concerned 
with  urban  transport planning and  implementation  needs  to  be  improved; (ii) participation of all 
agencies  with  responsibilities  for  urban  transport  is  key  to  developing  an  integrated  and 
sustainable project; and (iii) investment in urban roads needs to be complemented by improving 
other urban transport aspects, such as traffic management and safety, vehicle emission control, 
and road maintenance. These lessons are incorporated in the project design.

Rationale 

E. 
 
The  overall  objective  of  the  country  strategy  and  program 24   is  to  promote  pro-poor 
21. 
economic  growth  by  giving  the  poor  greater  access  to  opportunities  and  benefits  of  economic 
prosperity.  The  strategy  is  designed  to  (i)  promote  equitable  and  inclusive  growth,  (ii)  make 
markets  work  more  effectively,  (iii)  protect  the  environment,  and  (iv)  promote cooperation with 
neighboring countries. An essential thrust of the strategy is to increase assistance to the  poor 
central and western provinces, including Shaanxi Province,  by supporting projects that facilitate 
pro-poor  economic  growth.  In  the  transport  sector,  the  strategy  will  help  remove  transport 
infrastructure  constraints  and  improve  the  urban  environment.  An  efficient,  safe,  and 
environmentally  sustainable  transport  network  is  needed  to  promote  economic  growth  and 
benefit the poor  in urban and rural areas. Urban infrastructure, such as road transport systems 
and  public  utilities,  will  need  to  be  improved  to  cope  with  the  increasing  burden  as  a  result  of 
rapid  urbanization.  The  proposed  Project,  designed  to  remove  transport  bottlenecks  and 
address environmental concerns in Xi’an, one of the major growth centers in the western region, 
is  consistent  with  PRC’s  development  priorities  and  ADB’s strategy.  The  proposed  Project  is 
also consistent with ADB’s urban sector strategy,25 which supports investing in the urban sector 
because  of the central role urban centers  play  in  economic  growth.  Urban areas are dynamic 
engines of growth and employment creation, centers for innovation and  entrepreneurship, and 
sources of social services. 
 
22. 
Consistent  with  the  Xi’an  master  plan,  large  investments  are  programmed  for  road 
construction,  a  subway  system,  and  public  transport  operations.  Clear  and  realistic  priorities 
need  to  be  set  for  future  urban  development.  Policy  and  institutional  reforms  are needed  in 
urban  transport  policy  and  regulations,  public  transport,  traffic  management  and  safety,  road 
maintenance, vehicle emission control,  driver education,  urban poverty reduction, and  private 
sector  development.  The  master plan  gives  priority  to  the  construction  of  the  third  ring  road 
(TRR)  shown  in  Map  2,  which  will  form  the  main  physical  component  of  the  Project. 
Construction of a ring road and connector roads will provide efficient and safe access within the 
city,  and  for  inbound  and  outbound  traffic.  The  Project  will  address  the  growing  traffic 
congestion  caused  by  the  rapid  increase  in  traffic,  inadequate  road  infrastructure,  and  poor 
traffic management. The Project has been designed as a public  service project because people 
in  the  urban  area  will  all  benefit  from  the  Project  directly  or  indirectly  through  reduced 
congestion in the urban road network as a whole. The project road users, therefore, will not be 
directly charged for its use. Xi’an municipality has identified the Project as a priority investment, 
which  will  also  complement  ADB’s assistance  in  developing  the  Xi’an-Taiyuan  section  of the 
national trunk highway system.26

without-project  situations.  The Project  will  provide  relief  for  the  increasingly  congested  central

accidents. Environmental benefits will result from avoided vehicular emissions as a result of the

Road Safety Audit Program 

 
4. 
Implementing an effective road safety audit program is an efficient  way to improve road 
safety conditions and to reduce the number and severity of accidents. A road safety audit is a 
formal  examination  of  existing  or  future  road  conditions,  which  interacts  with  road  users.  An 
independent,  qualified  examiner  reports  on  the  project's  accident  potential  and  safety 
performance. A road safety audit considers all road users, including various pedestrian groups, 
cyclists,  motorcyclists,  and  operators  of  heavy  vehicles.  It  relies  heavily  on  established 
guidelines  and  standards,  and  also  on  the  ability  of  the  auditor  to  recognize  a  potentially 
hazardous combination of elements, which may not be covered by specific guidelines. The main 
reason  for  conducting  road  safety  audits  is  to  prevent  road  accidents  by  identifying  potential 
safety problems that may require corrective action. Road safety audits seek to ensure that, as 
far as practicable, road and traffic schemes are safe and fit for the purpose for which they are 
intended. The project roads will be subject to road safety audit during the design stage and prior 
to  opening.  The  Project  will  also  include  a  comprehensive  road  safety  audit  program  across 
Xi’an  by  ensuring  that  (i)  elements  that  could  cause  accidents    (e.g.,  road  furniture  near  the 
edge of traffic lanes) are not present in the road network; (ii) elements that could reduce the risk 
of road accidents (e.g., anti-skid surfacing) are included in the operational road network; and (iii) 
elements that reduce the severity of road accidents  (e.g., accident barriers) are included in the 
overall road network.

6.

Poverty  Impacts.  The  Project  will  have  both  direct  and  indirect  impacts  on  poverty.   
Direct  impacts  will  be  derived  from  construction  employment  opportunities,  savings  in  travel 
time, and the potential for vehicle cost savings in passenger transport (buses) to be passed on 
to  passengers.  The  Project  will  benefit  the  local  poor  and  migrant  workers  by  hiring  unskilled 
and  semiskilled  labor  for  construction  activities.  It  has  been  observed  that  most  of  the  job 
opportunities  in  other  road  construction  projects  in  and  around  Xi’an  go  to  the  poor  since  the 
work is arduous and relatively low paying compared with other opportunities in the city. On-the-
job training to be provided will improve the chances for reemployment once road construction is 
complete.  The  poor  will  benefit  from  employment  and  income  generation  opportunities  that 
result  from  the  third  ring  road  (TRR)  and  induced  urbanization.  Congestion  on  the  first  and 
second ring roads will be reduced, and travel times will improve by 1–2 km/hour over the entire 
network, generating substantial economic benefit for all users.

beyond  the  TRR  and  orbital  road,  which  will  improve  access  to  the  satellite  towns  and  rural 
areas. The poor will benefit from trickle down effects from improvements in the  local economy. 
Accelerated  urbanization  related  to  the  construction  of  the  TRR  will  give  households  more 
opportunities  to  diversify  income.  Household  poverty  and  vulnerability  will  be  reduced  with 
multiple  income  earners  and  more  than  one  source  of  income.  Survey data shows that rural 
households  with  incomes  over  and  above  that  derived  solely  from  agricultural  production  are 
better off than households that rely solely on farming (cropping or livestock).

Land Acquisition and Resettlement Impacts 

 
A. 
 
The third ring road (TRR) and upgraded connector roads will pass through 3 districts, 17 
1. 
wards, and 105 villages. The project components will permanently occupy 1,000 hectares (ha), 
of which 839 ha is owned by village collectives and requires compensation. Efforts were made 
to  reduce  resettlement  impacts  by  selecting  a  route  that  would  occupy  as  little  farmland  as 
possible  and  require  demolition  of  as  few  houses  as  possible.  The  alignment  was  close to 
villages without going through built-up areas. The general alignment of the ring road has been in 
the Xi’an master plan for many years. In many places the local government had restricted new 
construction along the proposed alignment. The decision to combine the northern and southern 
sections  with  the  orbital  road  reduced  the  amount  of  land  acquisition  by  170  ha  and  avoided 
475,059  square  meters  (m2)  of  buildings/houses,  thereby  reducing  the  number  of  people 
affected. During construction, an additional 330 ha will be used temporarily for 1–3 years. The 
floor  space  of  total  buildings/houses  lost  is  1.3  million  m2,  of  which  73%  is  village 
residential/commercial area and 27% institutional/enterprise premises.  
 
2. 
It is estimated that (i) 3,394 rural households will be affected only by land acquisition, (ii) 
540 rural households will be affected by both land acquisition and building/house relocation, (iii) 
2,736  rural  and  urban  households  will  be  affected  only  by  residential/commercial  area 
relocation, and  (iv)  151 enterprises with  a total staff of  5,087  will  be affected either directly or 
indirectly. A total of 29,044 persons will be affected, making up 2% of the total population in the 
three districts immediately affected by the Project (Table A15.1).

Resettlement Principles and Compensation 

 
B. 
 
3. 
Land  acquisition  is  governed  by  the  1998  Land  Administration  Law  of  the  People’s 
Republic of China, the 1999  Methods of Execution of the Land Administration Law in Shaanxi, 
and  the  2003  Management  Regulations  of  Xi ’an  Urban  Building  Removal.  Resettlement  will 
follow ADB’s Policy on Involuntary Resettlement and Social Protection Strategy, as well as the 
local resettlement practices for similar projects in Xi’an. The resettlement plan (RP) addresses 
losses and impacts on different groups, businesses, and structures. Based on the inventory of 
losses,  an  entitlement  matrix  was  developed,  which  recognizes  all  types  of  affected  persons 
(AP)  and  their  losses,  irrespective  of  ownership  or  registration  (Table  A15.2). Losses suffered 
by AP have been categorized as land loss, structure loss, land attachment loss, business/salary 
loss, and crop loss. 
 
The  main  objective of  the  RP  is  to  restore  and  improve  the  economic  condition of the 
4. 
APs,  particularly  vulnerable  groups.  Measures  such  as  a  transitional  allowance  for  lost 
livelihood,  business/economic  rehabilitation  support,  and  training  for  livelihoods  were  adopted. 
Economic  rehabilitation  will  be  partly  supported  by  employment  and  income  generation 
opportunities related to project construction works.

Stakeholder Participation, Disclosure of RP, and Grievances 

C. 
 
5. 
Since  the  Project  will  have  significant  impacts,  community  views  were  sought  through 
consultation meetings. Between July 2002 and February 2003, 33 focus group discussions were 
conducted, 1,550 households in 22 affected villages were surveyed, and owners of 20 affected 
enterprises  were  interviewed.  From  April  to  June  2003,  all  affected  villages  and  enterprises 
were investigated and consulted, and seriously affected villages formulated initial rehabilitation 
plans.  In  July  2003,  5,000  copies  of  a  resettlement  information booklet  were  distributed  to  all 
affected  villages,  households,  and  enterprises.  In  August,  the  approved  compensation 
standards and road alignment were announced to the local people.  At various stages of project 
planning,  APs  were  informed  of,  and  consulted  about,  the  likely  impacts  of  the  Project. 
Stakeholders  consulted  included  (i)  heads  of  households/business  units  to  be  affected;  (ii) 
village  heads  and  villagers’  representatives;  (iii)  local  government  agencies  and  departments; 
and  (iv)  women,  the  poor,  and  other  vulnerable  groups.  More  intensive  consultations  were 
undertaken to formulate village rehabilitation plans for the most seriously affected villages.  The 
consultations will continue throughout project implementation.  
 
6. 
The RP prepared by the Xi’an Municipal Third Ring Road Construction and Development 
Company  (Project  Company)  was  discus sed with  local  government  agencies  to  understand 
local and Asian Development Bank (ADB) policies, compensation standards, and resettlement 
strategy. Public consultation meetings held in each affected district verified local support for the 
Project. Regarding land acquisition and resettlement, there were concerns about adjusting the 
road  alignment,  improved  compensation  standards,  resettlement  options,  and  entitlements. 
Once the final design is approved, there will be a detailed measurement survey of the alignment 
and  compensation  agreements  will  be  signed  with  all  affected  villages,  households,  and 
enterprises.  
 
D.  
 
7. 
Resettlement  site  selection  was  considered  with  the  income  restoration  plans.  There 
were three options  in  selecting  residential  resettlement  sites:  (i)  for  areas  where  only several 
households  are  involved  in  house  relocation  (light  impact),  the  new  housing  sites  can  be 
selected  in  the  same  village/community;  (ii)  for  a  village  with  more  households  involved  in 
relocation, but with enough land for their livelihoods (intermediate impact), a site with existing or 
new  apartment  buildings  can  be  selected,  considering  farmers’  production  and  operational 
convenience;  or  (iii)  for  a  village  with  a  serious  relocation  impact,  a  separate  village 
rehabilitation  plan  was  formulated,  for  which  final  site  selection  will  be  determined  once  the 
project feasibility study is approved. For the relocated enterprises, new sites will be planned by 
the  Xi’an  Municipal Planning Commission. Each enterprise will be responsible for reemploying 
staff and contract workers, and will be assisted with subsidies where necessary. 
 
8. 
There  will  be  few  opportunities  for  agricultural  development  because  urbanization 
pressure  in  the  project  area  is  already  strong,  except  in  places  such  a  Chang’An  ancient  city 
where  investment  will  be  made  for  vegetable  gardening  and  animal  husbandry.  Fortunately, 
commercial  and  industrial  opportunities  near  the  new  ring  road  will  improve  significantly. 
Proposed  income  rehabilitation  measures  are  as  follows: (i)  provide employment opportunities 
in  new  commercial  and  industrial  enterprises,  (ii)  establish  collective  enterprises,  (iii)  open 
private shops and businesses, (iv) rent land and housing, and (v) provide subsidies and  social 
security  system   for  vulnerable  groups  and  poor  households.  Within  each  category,  detailed 
needs for farmers to  expand their working skills will be  identified,  and  relevant  training  will  be 
planned. For vulnerable groups, the Project will provide a special social assistance fund to  help 
each household restore its livelihood.

Implementation Framework and Budget 

E. 
 
9. 
On  behalf  of  the  Xi’an  municipal  government,  the  Xi’an  Municipal  Urban  and  Rural 
Construction  Commission  (XMURCC)  will  be  responsible  for  general  administration  and 
coordination  of  the  Project.  The  leading  group  and  a  permanent  office  were  established  to 
coordinate  interagency  responsibilities.  A  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  department  within 
the  Project  Company  was  established,  and  experienced  staff  were  recruited.  This  department 
will  supervise  and  assist  the  local  government  offices  that  will  implement  land  acquisition, 
compensation,  resettlement,  and  rehabilitation  and  resolving  grievances.  Resettlement 
coordination offices were established in each affected district and several wards. Each affected 
village will appoint at least one person as a member of the ward office to assist with preparing 
and  implementing  relocation  and  economic  rehabilitation  plans.  Each  village  or  neighborhood 
committee will be actively involved with implementing resettlement. 
 
10. 
In July 2003, the Xi’an municipal government approved the compensation standards for 
the  Project.  Detailed  impact  investigations  have  been  completed  and  provide  accurate 
quantities for the cost estimate. Based on the compensation rates, and the estimated impacts 
based on preliminary design data, the budget for land  acquisition and resettlement is estimated 
at  $180.5  million  equivalent,  excluding  contingencies.  This  is  relatively  high  because  of  the 
location of the ring road in the relatively densely populated suburban area. Most of the land is 
owned  by  rural  collectives,  and  hence  the  land  compensation  needs  to  be  paid  at  a  high 
average rate of CNY25,000 per 0.067 hectare in addition to relocation costs for residences and 
enterprises.  
 
The Project Company will establish a system for internal monitoring of land acquisition 
11. 
and resettlement to guarantee timely and adequate land acquisition and resettlement works in 
accordance with the  RP  and  to  ensure  the  entitlements  of  the  AP  are  fully  met.  The  Project 
Company  will  summarize  resettlement  progress  in  the  quarterly  reports  it  submits  to  ADB.  At 
midterm  and  at  project  completion,  the  Project  Company  will  submit  resettlement  evaluation 
reports  to  ADB  that  summarize  achievements,  outstanding  issues,  and  remedial  measures. 
Each  year,  the  XMURCC  will  submit  to  ADB  a  summary  of  the  annual  resettlement  audit  of 
disbursements and expenditures, prepared by the Xi’an Municipal Audit Bureau. Resettlement 
supervision milestones have been agreed upon (Table A15.3). 
 
12. 
The  Project  Company  will  hire  an  independent  institute  for  external  monitoring  and 
evaluation  of  resettlement.  The  tasks  follow:  (i)  prepare  the  baseline  data,  (ii)  verify  the 
adequacy  and  timeliness  of  compensation  payments,  (iii)  assess  economic  rehabilitation 
measures  and  adequacy  of  the  budget,  (iv)  assess  the  quality  of  new  house  construction  and 
timely  transfer,  (v)  appraise  the  effectiveness  of  the  grievance  procedure,  (vi)  collect opinions 
and  level  of  satisfaction  of  APs,  (vii)  assess  the  efficiency  and  effectiveness  of  agencies 
responsible for resettlement, (viii) survey households to assess whether they have restored or 
improved  their  living  conditions  and  income  levels,  and  (ix)  assess  the  rehabilitation  of 
enterprises and redeployment of staff and contract workers. External monitoring will be carried 
out  every  6  months  in  the  first  2  years,  and  then  annually  for  2–3  years.  Monitoring  and 
evaluation reports will be submitted to the Project Company and ADB.
